article_title: Affordable Care Act adds paperwork to federal tax returns
article_text:
Affordable Care Act adds paperwork to federal tax returns Many lacking health care coverage are learning whether they will confront penalties for not signing up

Photo: Karen Warren, Staff H&R Block office manager Dianne Butler, left, sits with her...

Claudia Chacon, a dental assistant and mother of two young children, earns just over $20,000 a year and typically gets more than $1,000 back from Uncle Sam each spring. She relies on this federal tax refund to catch up on bills and care for her family.

article_metadata.description: Many lacking health care coverage are learning whether they will confront penalties for not signing up  [...] learning how they will be affected by Obamacare's tax requirements are the nearly 7 million Americans who purchased coverage through its federal health insurance marketplace.  If they miscalculated the size of the subsidy they were entitled to, they will have to pay the difference, up to $1,250 for an individual or $2,500 for a household, back to the government.  Most of the nation's estimated 25 million to 30 million tax filers simply will check a box indicating they had employer-based insurance or received health coverage under a government program such as Medicare or Medicaid.  Officials say 85 percent of those who bought coverage in 2014 qualified for tax credits, often called subsidies, to reduce their premium costs.  [...] a survey in October that Pickering's institute conducted found over 65 percent of survey respondents did not know tax credits they accepted to lower premium costs could affect their returns.  Tax and health coverage enrollment experts advise marketplace consumers  to update their incomes and report life changes, such as marriages, births, adoptions and divorces, to avoid problems at tax time.
article_metadata.author.name: By Lora Hines

og.description: Many lacking health care coverage are learning whether they will confront penalties for not signing up  [...] learning how they will be affected by Obamacare's tax requirements are the nearly 7 million Americans who purchased coverage through its federal health insurance marketplace.  If they miscalculated the size of the subsidy they were entitled to, they will have to pay the difference, up to $1,250 for an individual or $2,500 for a household, back to the government.  Most of the nation's estimated 25 million to 30 million tax filers simply will check a box indicating they had employer-based insurance or received health coverage under a government program such as Medicare or Medicaid.  Officials say 85 percent of those who bought coverage in 2014 qualified for tax credits, often called subsidies, to reduce their premium costs.  [...] a survey in October that Pickering's institute conducted found over 65 percent of survey respondents did not know tax credits they accepted to lower premium costs could affect their returns.  Tax and health coverage enrollment experts advise marketplace consumers  to update their incomes and report life changes, such as marriages, births, adoptions and divorces, to avoid problems at tax time.
